content.text:
[@nanomonkey](@+D0ku/LReK6kqd3PSrcVCfbLYbDtTmS4Bd21rqhpYNA=.ed25519)

> Specially since it's easier to utilize solar heated water later in the day instead of earlier. 

How do you use solar heated water? I imagine you own a house? I'm [currently] stuck with apartment living, but I'm *really* looking forward to managing some of my own needs rather than outsourcing everything to property """management""".

[@ibob](@vkdMlsuBgzzo5eLS3LZLdqnBpZ26OauJOMIq9gQ2E7E=.ed25519)

I've never had (or made) white sweet tea -- anything I should know, or should I just dive in feet first?

[@kas](@dBQlwh9Gtr3i5YMOGtIOKtGNVepeu+nyb6KGl1vtOcM=.ed25519)

Same as above except with oat milk, never tried it, but I should really experiment a bit more with non-dairy milk. I stopped using dairy around two years ago but never even considered replacing it rather than just removing it from my diet.

[@glyph](@HEqy940T6uB+T+d9Jaa58aNfRzLx9eRWqkZljBmnkmk=.ed25519)

> Getting an under-cut (back and sides) has been a revelation! So much less hair to manage, while still reppin' them luscious locks.

Do you have any photos? I don't think I've seen an undercut with a top that goes down to the mid-back, but I'm super curious!

[@glyph](@HEqy940T6uB+T+d9Jaa58aNfRzLx9eRWqkZljBmnkmk=.ed25519) and [@nanomonkey](@+D0ku/LReK6kqd3PSrcVCfbLYbDtTmS4Bd21rqhpYNA=.ed25519)) 

I *loved* wool, but since giving up animal products I've been having a hard time finding a replacement. Natural non-animal fibers are often inexpensive and comfortable, but living in the Pacific Northwest (and doing volunteer search and rescue) in a predominantly wet area makes me hesitant to use cellulose fibers that are mostly hygroscopic. On the other hand, [some folks](http://woodtrekker.blogspot.com/2012/11/cotton-vs-wool-insulation.html#uds-search-results) are skeptical of wool's "insulates even when wet" property, although it's anti-odor properties are pretty clear IMO. I also found [a study from 1944](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/jres/32/jresv32n5p229_A1b.pdf) with all sorts of fibers and fabrics, but I'm *sure* there's better science out there.
